commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've got the Titrator and TitrationMove working. It is not as clean as I would like, but it will let
me test to see if this is a good idea... ;-)

I've added an example script (test/SireMove/titrationmove.py)

I've also fixed the inRing(dihedral) function to fix the phenol bug (C-C-O-H is not in a ring...!)

Code compiles, links and runs as expected

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
Ported the fix for the linear angle bug to Julien's branch, and have added in the change
to ConnectivityEditor needed to allow test/SireMol/linearmols.py to run.

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message: Updated python wrappers for the next commit

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've fixed a small bug that causes an exception to be raised on rare occasions when moving the angle
of linear groups. I've also added a "disconnectAll()" function to Connectivity, added in a NullBondHunter 
class so that empty Connectivity objects can be created, and added a test for moving linear molecules.

I am also committed my work to date on the TitrationMove (most of this is stubbed and non-functional)

Code compiles, links and works as expected.

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message: Python wrappers needed for the next commit...

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message: These are the python wrappers which accompany the new Connectivity code

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've merged the changes needed to support ring moves, have tidied up the print out from
Exception::toString() (to stop you having to scroll up all of the time!) and have also
edited Flexibility to properly version the binary data stream for this object.

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've fixed a small bug in the findPaths routine that caused a second path to be skipped
when the ring appeared in the middle of the chain (e.g. a proline in a chain should add
two paths along the CA backbone of the protein - one around the proline ring and one
along the backbone - the bug skipped one of them out). This slows down the path
hunting as the fix causes lots or reallocs of the "done" list of parsed atoms. 

I've tested this on a big protein and the paths I get all seem sensible ;-)

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've filled in the stub functions and it is now possible to query whether two, three or four atoms are
part of a ring. I've also added a "findPaths" function that finds all bonded pathways between two
atoms in a molecule (in the Connectivity object). See test/SireMol/ringmoves.py for an example that
uses this function to print the paths between the ends of the moved bond, angle and dihedral.

Code compiles, links and works as expected.

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
Updated python wrappers for the next commit of corelib...

(this version is broken, as it needs the next commit of corelib)

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
Committing the python wrappers for the updated Connectivity class. Note that the current
version on the repository uses stubs for Connectivity::inRing(...), so it will produce
erroneous results!

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've updated the Connectivity class so that moves in rings are now permitted (removing the
need for a ring_error exception). I've also added in stubs for a inRing(..) function that
allows users to detect rings without relying on ring_errors begin raised.

I've added a test (test/SireMol/ringmoves.py) that test the ring moves and demonstrate the
range of motion possible using oseltamivir.

I've also added in all of the files for the Sire tutorial I ran at Bristol and Edinburgh.

Code compiles, runs and produces output as expected.

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've updated the grid forcefield and have checked it with WSRC against the InterGroupCLJFF. There
is almost perfect agreement (perfect for LJ, just ~0.05 kcal mol-1 in ~4000 kcal mol-1 total
energy for coulomb, osel in neura). The WSRC simulations using GridFF and InterGroupCLJFF also
give about the same behaviour and free energies.

commits.message: Python wrappers for the next commit

commits.author: nividic73@gmail.com
commits.message: I've started the modification on aMD and single topology

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've restored the original amber.zmatrices from Julien, with the original move deltas. I think 
that the GridFF bug I fixed in the last update caused the move delta problems I was seeing. I've
also added the CYM (deprotonated cysteine) to amber.zmatrices

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've fixed a bug in the latest version of the GridFF forcefield that was causing it to not update
the LJ parameter matrix after being re-read from a binary data file. This caused the LJ energy
to be incorrect. I've updated the test/SireMM/testgridff.py test script so that it simultaneously
calculates the "correct" and "grid" energies for loading, saving, moving and recalculating a 
system and have confirmed that the energies now agree to about <0.01 kcal mol-1 for a 0.5 A grid.

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've changed the streaming of the grid forcefield so that it saves and restores the
complete grid. This stops the grid forcefield expensively recalculating the grid all 
of the time, and also allows replicas in a replica exchange simulation to share the 
memory requirements for each grid.

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've fixed bugs in the GridFF forcefield and also updated the ZMatMove class. This is to restore
the ability for the code to calculate changes in energies of only parts of a molecule when they
move, rather than for the whole molecule.

IMPORTANT - I have also play around a bit with the move deltas for the protein (amber.zmatricies).
I've halved the dihedral and angle deltas, as I was seeing that the acceptance ratio for 
the existing values for zmat moves was only about 10%, while this change raises the acceptance
ratio to 45%.
